CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL of LAW ( “ the CAP ” ) ( ORG postępowania administracyjnego ) , which sets out grounds on which a final administrative decision is subject to annulment , states :

CARDINAL ) it has a flaw making it null and void by the force of law .
There is no time - limit for a party ’s request to have an administrative decision declared null and void under LAW .

However , there are situations where , even if certain grounds listed in LAW exist , the lapse of time or irreversible effects of the contested decision have consequences for the formula used in a decision given in the annulment procedure . LAW provides for the following exceptions :

“ A decision shall not be declared null and void on the grounds listed in paragraph CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) , ( CARDINAL ) , ( CARDINAL ) and ( CARDINAL ) if DATE have expired from the date of its service or promulgation , as well as if the decision has produced irreversible legal effects . ”
Article CARDINAL reads as follows :
“ CARDINAL . A ruling on annulment of a decision shall be given by means of a decision .

CARDINAL . If it is impossible to declare a decision null and void because of the circumstances referred to in LAW , a public administration authority shall only declare that the contested decision has been issued contrary to the law and indicate circumstances because of which it has not declared the decision null and void . ”
For the purposes of compensation , the effects of declaring the original administrative decision “ null and void ” or “ issued contrary to the law ” are the same .
